items.title: Vulcan version 4.0 high-resolution annual carbon dioxide emissions in the U.S. for the 2010–2022 time period
items.body:
Download PDF

Data Descriptor
    
        
            Open access

Published: 17 December 2025

Vulcan version 4.0 high-resolution annual carbon dioxide emissions in the U.S. for the 2010–2022 time period
                    Kevin R. Gurney 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-9218-71641, Pawlok Dass 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-3957-40551, Anna Kato 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-2758-68171, Lech Gawuc1, Bilal Aslam1 & …Huilin Sun 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0009-0006-6463-01421 Show authors

Scientific Data

volume 12, Article number: 1946 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate-change mitigationEnergy supply and demand

AbstractThis paper describes Vulcan version 4.0, a dataset representing annual United States carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from the combustion of fossil fuel and cement production at high spatial resolution for the 2010–2022 time period. It updates the Vulcan version 3.0 data product previously reported in the literature. While the “native” spatial resolution of Vulcan is at the point, line, and US Census block spatial scale, we report here on the results placed into a 1 km × 1 km spatial grid at an annual time resolution. The approach uses multiple federal, state, and local data sources to estimate the CO2 emission magnitude and distribute those emissions in space and time. Given the increased interest in greenhouse gas mitigation at sub-national scales, this data offers a better understanding of the emitting landscape enabling more targeted, efficient policy instruments. The Vulcan output offers the scientific community CO2 emissions applicable to a wide range of study fields, including carbon cycle science, climate science, environmental policy, urban planning, and socioeconomic research.

Background & SummaryGlobal emissions of carbon dioxide from the combustion of fossil fuels (FFCO2) remain the largest net flux of carbon into the Earth’s atmosphere and the primary driver of anthropogenic climate change1. Improving quantitative understanding of FFCO2 fluxes contributes to advancing climate change research and climate change policymaking, particularly efforts aimed at GHG emissions mitigation2. For example, scientific understanding of the global carbon cycle and how it interacts with climate change rests on accurate quantification of FFCO2 emissions at multiple space and time scales3,4,5. This, in turn, improves the reliability of future projections of climate change and specifies the emissions reductions necessary to meet specific targets, such as limiting the rise of global mean temperature to 1.5 °C6. Understanding FFCO2 sources also assists in understanding the composition, driving factors, and responsibility for emissions, making mitigation options better targeted, equitable, and ultimately more effective7,8,9.Systematic quantification of FFCO2 emissions began over 5 decades ago and with efforts to assess total emissions at the global and national spatial scales in order to better understand the drivers of climate change and the global carbon cycle10. Since those early efforts, the research community has quantified FFCO2 emissions at multiple scales from building to global scales, for differing time periods, using a variety of estimation techniques. For a review of this research11,12,13.The focus of the data presented here is on estimation of high-resolution FFCO2 emissions for the U.S. national domain and represents an update of the Vulcan Project FFCO2 emissions from the previous version 3.0 to this version 4.0. As such, we refer the reader to previous publications describing Vulcan where common methods, literature review, and further context is provided13,14,15,16.Updates to the Vulcan FFCO2 estimation represented by version 4.0 include extension of the time period covered, algorithmic improvements, underlying resolution improvements, and updated data inputs. This makes the updated version useful to more contemporary decisionmaking support and better integration with emission estimation methods that use atmospheric measurements.MethodsThe study domain is the United States, the fourth-largest country in the world (covering approximately 9.8 million square kilometers) with a population of over 333 million people as of 2022. The FFCO2 emission estimates presented here are Scope 1 (i.e., territorial) only and cover 49 states (Hawaii is available in non-gridded form upon request) and the District of Columbia but do not include the U.S. territories (e.g., Puerto Rico). The geographic resolution of the data is 1 km × 1 km and the study period covers the years 2010 to 2022. These have also been aggregated to the county and state scale. The FFCO2 emissions presented also include sub-categorization by sector (electricity production, industrial, commercial, residential, airport, nonroad, onroad, railroad, commercial marine vessels, and cement production) and fuel type (coal, petroleum, and natural gas). Cement production includes both the emissions due to the combustion of fossil fuels and the stochiometric release of CO2 during calcining.As an update to the Vulcan version 3.0 FFCO2 emissions data product, much of the methodological details of Vulcan version 4.0 are consistent with the methods for Vulcan version 3.0. Here, we primarily notate methodological changes and updates to version 4.0 while succinctly summarizing the Vulcan methodology of the previous version 3.0 for completeness and clarity. For the greatest amount of detail on the methods followed by Vulcan version 3.0, the reader is referred to13,14. We describe the methods following the sector and/or data type description accompanying the input data. The data types refer to the geographic representation of the emissions data: point or nonpoint, while the sectors refer to the commonly categorized economic sectors: electricity production, commercial, industrial, residential, onroad, airport, railroad, nonroad, commercial marine vessels, and cement production.Nonpoint (i.e., area) source emissions are stationary sources of FFCO2 emissions that are not inventoried or specified at the individual facility, building, or release point scale and can be thought of as representing dispersed sources within a geographic area. These are primarily building emissions, onroad emissions, railroad emissions, and emissions from commercial marine vessels. Point source emissions, by contrast, represent FFCO2 emissions explicitly linked to a stationary release point (i.e., a physically identifiable emission “stack”) or emitting facility. These emissions include emission stacks on buildings (in the electricity production, commercial, cement, and industrial sectors), airports (the aircraft emitting component), and a small amount of railroad and nonroad (defined later).The sector definitions generally follow commonly used application in GHG emissions quantification but a few warrant additional clarity. For example, the electricity production sector includes facilities that produce electricity and are connected to an electrical grid system. Furthermore, like all the sources included in Vulcan v4.0, they only reflect the combustion of fossil fuels. Power production based on non-CO2 emitters such as renewable sources are not included. The nonroad sector includes all mobile fossil fuel combustion devices that are not considered legal for use on roadways. These include traditional off-road vehicles plus devices such as lawnmowers in addition to waterborne vehicles aside from commercial marine vessels, which are separately managed in the commercial marine vessels sector. Airport emissions include all aircraft emissions during the taxi, takeoff, and landing cycles up to 3000 feet. Baggage carriers and other mobile airport equipment are included in the nonroad sector. Airport buildings are included in the commercial sector. Cement production includes both the FFCO2 emissions resulting from the combustion of fossil fuels and the stoichiometric release of CO2 during the calcining process. The latter is the only non-fossil source in Vulcan and is included because of the common norm of doing so and the magnitude of this process which, among the “process” emissions in the U.S., is the largest.Some sectors will reflect input data of both point and nonpoint data types while others will reflect input data of only one data type. For example, the industrial sector contains input data of both point and nonpoint while the residential sector only contains nonpoint source reporting data.Table 1 provides an overview of the data sources used in generating Vulcan version 4.0 FFCO2 emissions including data used to further downscale or condition the data in space and time. Data changes/updates in Vulcan version 4.0 are noted separately.Table 1 Overview of data sources used in generating the space/time-resolved Vulcan v4.0 FFCO2 emissions (footnotes provide acronym explanations).Full size tableElectricity productionVulcan electricity production FFCO2 emissions represent 13,814 grid-connected power generation facilities in 2022. These have been published as a pointwise data product: Vulcan-power version v1.017. In short, these emissions are built from three data sources: the Environmental Protection Agency’s Clean Air Markets Program Data (CAMPD) (Carbon Pollution Emission Guidelines for Existing Stationary Sources 2015; https://campd.epa.gov)18, the Department of Energy’s Energy Information Administration (EIA) EIA-923 survey data (https://www.eia.gov/electricity/data/eia923/index.php), and the United States Environmental Protection Agency’s 2014 and 2017 National Emissions Inventories (NEI)19,20,21,22. Though the CAMPD data set does not include all power plants in the United States, it accounts for 91.6% of the U.S. electricity production FFCO2 emissions in 2022. It reports CO2 emissions based on direct monitoring in the effluent stack. The EIA-923 reporting includes the heat input value (e.g., British thermal units) for each U.S. electricity production facility exceeding a nameplate capacity of 1 MW. FFCO2 emission factors are then utilized to calculate the quantity of FFCO2 emitted from these EIA-923 facilities23. After the removal of the overlap with the CAMPD facilities (keeping the CAMPD facilities), these EIA facilities account for 7.7% of the FFCO2 emissions in the electricity production sector beyond that reported by CAMPD. The NEI reports carbon monoxide (CO) emissions from smaller electricity production facilities and these are processed to FFCO2 emissions using CO and CO2 emission factors gathered from extensive literature review (see Table 2 and13. Further detail on processing of the NEI-based facilities (for other sectors) is discussed below.Table 2 Heat value, carbon monoxide (CO) emission factor (EF), and carbon dioxide (CO2) emission factor for Vulcan version 4.0 emission sources.Full size tableA hierarchy was employed given that there was overlap between the three datasets. This was performed at the unit level given that a single facility might have individual power units reporting to, for example, CAMPD and another only reporting to the EIA. Where overlap did exist at this scale, preference was made to retain the CAMPD data, then the EIA, and finally the NEI. The choice of using the CAMPD emissions reporting over the EIA reporting is detailed in23 and is primarily motivated by analysis indicating that the direct stack monitoring is more accurate than the estimation from fuel inputs.Point sourcesThe point emissions represent facilities reported in the 2014 and 2017 NEI with a physically identifiable emission stack or point location and exceed a specific criteria air pollution threshold19. Vulcan version 4.0 follows the same approach as that taken in Vulcan version 3.0. However, the core input data from the NEI now utilizes the 2014 and 2017 NEI releases as opposed to the 2011 NEI release used in Vulcan version 3.021,24. The point processing includes sources classified as industrial, commercial, airport, railroad, and nonroad emitters. Airport, railroad, and nonroad are discussed separately below as they require additional processing beyond that described in this section. Hence, we describe the point processing in the industrial and commercial sectors here.Vulcan reports FFCO2 emissions for 50720 and 51284 individual facilities in 2014 and 2017, respectively. A number of key fields define a point location for the purposes of the Vulcan point FFCO2 emissions estimation and include the state and county FIPS code, the“state facility identifier” (which identifies the individual emitting facility), and the tribal code (used in place of the FIPS in tribal lands). Each site or facility can have multiple emission points (different“stacks”), emission units (different buildings or portions of a complex facility or site), or emission processes (e.g., energy production, heaters, engines). Some of these have different geocoded locations and these are retained in the Vulcan processing. These were not systematically inspected for location accuracy except in urban domains associated with the Hestia Project: the Los Angeles Megacity, the NE Corridor, Salt Lake City, and Indianapolis25,26,27,28,29.Each point emission record from the 2014 and 2017 NEI contains a source classification code (SCC), a numerical sequence that identifies characteristics of the emitting entity including sector, fuel, and combustion technology30. Most importantly, each record reports the amount of CO emissions. Both (SCC and CO amounts) are essential to the retrieval of appropriate CO and CO2 emission factors (EFs) used to transform the CO emissions into CO2 emissions. Fossil fuel CO2 emissions are created from the facility CO reporting through the application of CO and CO2 emission factors, as follows:$${E}_{n,f}^{{{CO}}_{2}}=\frac{{E}_{n,f}^{{CO}}}{{{EF}}_{n,f}^{{CO}}}{{EF}}_{n,f}^{{{CO}}_{2}}$$
                    (1)
                where \({E}_{n,f}^{{{CO}}_{2}}\), are the CO2 emissions for a process n (e.g. industrial 10 MMBTU boiler, industrial gasoline reciprocating turbine) and fuel f (e.g. natural gas, bituminous coal); \({E}_{n,f}^{{CO}}\) are the equivalent amount of CO emissions for a process n and fuel f; \({{EF}}_{n,f}^{{CO}}\) is the CO emission factor for a process n and fuel f; and \({{EF}}_{n,f}^{{{CO}}_{2}}\) is the CO2 EF for a process n and fuel f.The point source emitting process is matched to a CO EF via the SCC from the U.S. EPA WebFIRE EF database as the first choice for the CO EF (https://cfpub.epa.gov/webfire/). Where no match is found, default CO EF values are used, themselves archived from literature review (see Table 2) and determined through a combination of the sector and fuel.The use of two different NEI reporting cycles required some temporal harmonization. As with Vulcan version 3.0, the complete 2010–2022 time series is constructed by state/sector/fuel scaling supplied by the EIA State Energy Data System (SEDS)31. This multiyear scaling is to either the anchor data year of 2014 (for years 2010-2013, 2015) or the anchor data year 2017 (years 2016, 2018–2022). However, inspection of the complete time series made clear that the two NEI reporting cycles were likely not internally consistent and showed suspicious emission changes between 2014 and 2017 at many individual point facilities in the complete point multiyear results. It is not possible to trace the source of these unlikely changes in emissions between the NEI reporting cycles. A time series smoothing approach was employed to reduce this temporal inconsistency. An adjustment factor is created for the 2010 to 2015 time period and the 2016 to 2022 (or current end year) time period at the facility scale. This is done by differencing the 2014 and 2017 values for each facility record common between the two years and comparing that to the mean of the first and second time period standardized variances (the “background” variance). If the jump (expressed as a standardized variance) exceeds the background variance, 1/2 the absolute exceedance is added/subtracted from the respective years (2014, 2017) to moderate the jump. If the jump standardized variance does not exceed the background variance or either year has a zero value, no action is taken. The choice to avoid this scaling when one or the other year has zero emissions at a common facility is to allow instances where there is a cessation of activity at a facility (i.e., out of business or economic downturn). Given the impact this can have on the two anchor reporting years, multiyear scaling with the SEDS data is repeated after this adjustment to the complete time series.The point industrial sector FFCO2 emissions in the year 2014 are decreased by 7.38% while the point industrial FFCO2 emissions in 2017 are increased by 9.2% as a result of this adjustment. The number of individual industrial facilities impacted by the adjustment was 41.5% of the total point industrial facilities, indicating that these were smaller emitters exhibiting the relatively sudden changes in emissions between the two NEI reporting years. In the commercial sector the equivalent changes are −8.99%/ +12.6% which impacted 42.9% of facilities. In the electricity production sector, the equivalent changes are −7.2%/ +8.9% impacting 25.3% of facilities. However, given that the NEI-based electricity production only accounts for 1.1% of the electricity production FFCO2 emissions total, these changes remain very small in context.Further development is made in Vulcan version 4.0 by incorporating facility emissions reported to the electricity production sector in the EIA data noted in the previous section but for which the sole source consumer is either a commercial or industrial entity. These are identified as such in the EIA electricity production reporting and categorized as either commercial or industrial emission sources as appropriate and include as such.Additional updates have been made to the CO and CO2 emission factors used in processing the point source CO emissions from the NEI reporting. The values used in point and nonpoint (next section) processing are shown in Table 2.NonpointNonpoint emissions as reported in the 2014 and 2017 NEI encompass diffuse sources of emissions that are not reported via the point reporting or via reporting for onroad emissions20,22. Nonpoint emissions contribute to, or fully constitute, emissions in the residential, commercial, industrial, nonroad, railroad, and commercial marine vessels (CMV) sectors used in Vulcan. As with the point source emissions methodology, the procedures are consistent with those described in the Vulcan version 3.0 data product with some exceptions. As with point emissions, the core input data from the NEI now utilizes the 2014 and 2017 NEI releases as opposed to the 2011 NEI release used in Vulcan version 3.0.The use of two different NEI reporting cycles required temporal harmonization in much the same way as performed in the point source data processing. The complete 2010-2022 time series is constructed by state/sector/fuel type scaling supplied by the EIA SEDS data. This multiyear scaling is to either the data year of 2014 (for years 2010-2013, 2015) or the data year 2017 (years 2016, 2018-2022). Similar jumps noted in the point data were evident in the nonpoint reporting albeit for spatial units of counties as opposed to facilities. A time series smoothing approach was employed to reduce this temporal inconsistency. An adjustment factor is created for the 2010 to 2015 time period and the 2016 to 2022 (or current end year) time period at the sector/county/fuel type scale. This is done by differencing the 2014 and 2017 values for each sector/county/fuel type record common between the two years and comparing that to the mean of the first and second time period standardized variances (the “background” variance). If the jump (expressed as a standardized variance) exceeds the background variance, 1/2 the absolute exceedance is added/subtracted from the respective years (2014, 2017) to moderate the jump. If the jump standardized variance does not exceed the background variance or either year has a zero value, no action is taken. Given the impact this can have on the two anchor reporting years, multiyear scaling with the SEDS data is repeated after this adjustment to the complete time series.The changes in the 2014 and 2017 emission magnitudes were smaller than needed in the point source data. Here, the nonpoint industrial sector FFCO2 emissions in the year 2014 are decreased by 1.04% while the nonpoint industrial FFCO2 emissions in 2017 are increased by 0.8% as a result of this adjustment. The number of individual industrial county/fuel combinations impacted by the adjustment was 25.4% of the total nonpoint industrial county/fuel combinations, indicating that these were small emitting counties exhibiting the relatively sudden changes in emissions between the two NEI reporting years. In the commercial sector the equivalent changes are −3.3%/ +2.9% which impacted 26.7% of county/fuel combinations. In the residential sector, the equivalent changes are +3.0%/−2.8% impacting 43.6% of the county/fuel combinations. In the railroad sector the equivalent changes are −1.1%/ +1.1% impacting 31.6% of the county/fuel combinations.An initial comparison of state/sector/fuel type sums of the nonpoint and point equivalent fuel consumption was made to the EIA SEDS fuel consumption data in the NEI years: 2014 and 2017. The aim was to adjust the state/sector/fuel type totals to match the EIA SEDS state/sector fuel type total consumption values. However, prior to scaling the NEI totals to the EIA SEDS totals, it was noted that there were individual county and whole state gaps for a few combinations of specific fuel types, sectors and county/states. Each of these missing instances is individually examined and gap-filled if there is evidence that fuel consumption was likely to have occurred. This included inspection such as, the presence of housing, natural gas infrastructure, fuel in one sector but missing in another (e.g., commercial natural gas in a county with adjacent residential buildings but missing residential natural gas), or LPG consumption (indicating limited pipeline natural gas). The gap-filled amounts were further debited from the EIA SEDS state/sector/fuel type totals.After the gap-filling procedure was completed, adjustment to match the revised EIA SEDS state/sector/fuel type totals was made. As noted previously, this adjustment operation takes into account the summation of both the point and nonpoint Vulcan CO2 emissions defined at the state spatial scale and for fuel type (coal, petroleum, natural gas) and sector (residential, commercial, industrial). This is due to the fact that EIA SEDS has no point-nonpoint distinction but reflects a total (point + nonpoint) for a sector/fuel combination.Adjustments to the Vulcan point + nonpoint state/sector/fuel totals are made to the nonpoint residential, commercial and industrial state totals for natural gas and petroleum fuel (aggregate) only. No adjustments are made to coal consumption in the residential and commercial sectors as it is established that coal emissions are small to non-existent in these sectors.The sector total for the point and nonpoint are compared to the equivalent EIA SEDS value and the difference used to adjust the nonpoint total as needed to match the EIA SEDS totals and the Vulcan totals at the state/sector/fuel type scale. A negative difference (Vulcan larger) requires an adjustment factor < 1: {1 + (Δ/Vulcan nonpoint)} where Δ is the difference between the EIA value and the sum of the Vulcan point + nonpoint. A positive difference (Vulcan smaller) requires an adjustment factor > 1: {1-(Δ/Vulcan nonpoint).With the further adjustment to the NEI base year CO2 emission amounts, it is necessary to perform the multiyear scaling again.The Vulcan version 4.0 increases the resolution of the subcounty distribution for the nonpoint residential, commercial, and industrial FFCO2 emissions from that of U.S. Census block-groups to U.S. Census blocks. U.S. Census blocks are defined as the smallest geographic unit for which the U.S. Census Bureau collects and tabulates demographic data. They vary in size depending upon the population density but in a typical city they are similar to a city block bounded by roaways on all sides. A U.S. Census block-group is a larger unit, often composed of a cluster of blocks, again varying in size across the U.S. landscape.The sub-county FFCO2 emissions distribution procedure follows the approach taken in Vulcan version 3.0 with some differences in input data. The downscaling uses the product of total building floor area (specific to a building class) within each U.S. Census block and an estimate of energy use intensity (EUI) specific to fuel type/census division/climate zone/building type.As in Vulcan version 3.0, the fuel-specific EUI values are calculated from the EIA residential, commercial, and industrial building energy consumption surveys. In Vulcan version 4.0, updates to the survey input data are made. For example, three survey microdata data sets are used for the residential sector32,33,34,35,36,37,38. For the commercial sector, the same vintage survey data was used as was used in Vulcan version 3.039,40. National industrial EUI values were updated to use the microdata surveyed for 201441,42. In all three sectors the energy summed consumption by fuel type/building type/census division/climate zone is divided by the linked summed floor area for that same fuel type/building type/census division/climate zone to arrive at a mean EUI value.In linking the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) building types (see next section) to the Residential Energy Consumption Survey (RECS)/ Commercial Buildings Energy Consumption Survey (CBECS)/Manufacturing Energy Consumption Survey (MECS) building types there was a recognition that in some cases the FEMA definition subsumes or includes multiple RECS/CBECS/MECS building types. Hence, new combination building types were created to best represent these combined instances. These new estimates of EUI based on the combinations can then be used in the downscaling calculation. These are shown in Table 3.Table 3 Crosswalk table for the FEMA to CBECS/RECS/MECS building typology.Full size tableThe aim is to have an EUI value for every combination of data source (CBECS/RECS/MECS), building type, census division, and climate zone. While most were filled with the EIA survey data, some cannot be calculated due to missing data and hence, a gap-filling procedure is deployed. For missing EUI values in the CBECS or RECS microdata, an average is created that is specific to the data source (CBECS or RECS)/building type/fuel type thereby averaging over census divisions (a national mean value). For MECS, we use a much simpler average (since there is no census division or climate zone distinction) and create a national average specific to fuel type only.Prior to downscaling to U.S. Census blocks, data from the American Community Survey (ACS) on the number of households in a U.S. Census block-group using a specific fuel type (e.g., coal, petroleum, Natural Gas) is deployed43. This allows for correct fuel type share allocation to the block-group scale (highest resolution available) for the residential sector only, which is then further downscaled to the census block scale. An exception to this is for the blast furnace gas and coke oven gas fuel types in which the adjustment is ±35%. The CO EF adjustment is based on estimates of the range found in the WebFIRE EF database and the self‐reported CO emission factors reported in the NEI. However, evaluation of the FFCO2 emissions at more aggregate scales can be accomplished via two different methods. The first is to compare the emissions to independent estimation using atmospheric 14CO2, a unique tracer for fossil fuel CO2. Published: 17 December 2025

Atypical warming pattern of strong 2023-24 El Niño boosts global temperatures to new 1.5 °C record
                    Ning Jiang1, Congwen Zhu 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-3663-44811, Michael J. McPhaden 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-8423-58052, Zeng-Zhen Hu 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-8485-34003, Tao Lian 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-7438-41104, Chen Zhou 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-1489-51435 & …Deliang Chen 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-0288-56186 Show authors

Communications Earth & Environment

volume 6, Article number: 1012 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Atmospheric dynamicsClimate changePhysical oceanography

AbstractDuring the 2023-24 El Niño, the July 2023–June 2024 average global mean surface temperature peaked at 1.58 °C above pre-industrial levels, associated with a record 0.36 °C year-over-year rise. Here we use statistical models and a Green’s Function method to explore the causes for this rise. We show that sea surface temperature accounts for ~92% of the interannual warming, highlighting the critical role of El Niño diversity. Unlike typical El Niños, dual tropical Pacific warming centers in 2023-24 and an eastward-extended North Atlantic jet stream synergistically amplified sea surface temperatures across tropical basins, accelerating the pace of global warming. From an energy balance perspective, ocean heat content accumulated during the preceding La Niña and a continuous increase in absorbed shortwave radiation over the ocean drove sea surface temperature rise. Accelerated warming may push the climate system closer to critical tipping points, emphasizing the need for enhanced monitoring, mitigation, and adaptation strategies.

IntroductionAfter rising to a record-breaking level in 2023, global mean surface temperature (GMST) in 2024 reached an unprecedented new record, with an increase of 1.55 °C above pre-industrial levels1,2.Notably, 2024 marked the first time that GMST surpassed the 1.5 °C threshold for an entire calendar year1, resulting in widespread extreme weather and climate disasters3,4. Indeed, by the end of February 2024, the 12-month rolling average GMST had already exceeded 1.5 °C (Supplementary Fig. 1). As per the Paris Climate Agreement5, if this threshold is exceeded for multiple decades or longer, it could indicate a new era fraught with heightened risks from dangerous climate change3,6,7,8, underscoring the critical need for accelerated climate action1,3,4.Understanding the factors responsible for the accelerated rise in GMST is essential for crafting effective mitigation and adaptation strategies9. GMST variations stem from both external forcing (e.g., greenhouse gases and anthropogenic aerosols) and natural climate variability10,11,12,13. Among these, El Niño–Southern Oscillation (ENSO) dominates year-to-year climate variation10,14, exerting distinct impacts on GMST during its warm (El Niño) and cold (La Niña) phases. During La Niña, subsurface ocean heat accumulates in the tropical western Pacific; during El Niño, elevated sea surface temperatures (SST) enhance air-sea heat fluxes, releasing oceanic heat to the atmosphere. This amplifies tropical atmospheric heating and accelerates GMST rise as happened in 2015–1615. Conversely, persistent eastern Pacific cooling can lead to a slowdown or hiatus in global warming, as witnessed during 1998–201316.Following a rare three-year (2020–23) La Niña17, the 2023-24 El Niño contributed to the consecutive years of record-breaking GMST in 2023 and 202418. Given the delay between El Niño emergence and the GMST response, and considering that ENSO events typically peak in November-January19, we define ENSO-years in this study as spanning from July to the following June. The average GMST in ENSO-year 2024 (July 2023-June 2024 average) reached a record high of 1.58 °C (Fig. 1a), associated with an unprecedented interannual increment (ΔGMST) of 0.36 °C relative to ENSO-year 2023 (Fig. 1b). Here, the symbol Δ denotes the change in a variable, specifically referring to the interannual change between two consecutive ENSO-years (i.e., \({\Delta {{{\rm{GMST}}}}}_{{{{\rm{ENSO}}}}-{{{\rm{year}}}}2024}={{{{\rm{GMST}}}}}_{{{{\rm{ENSO}}}}-{{{\rm{year}}}}2024}-{{{{\rm{GMST}}}}}_{{{{\rm{ENSO}}}}-{{{\rm{year}}}}2023}\)).Fig. 1: Observed and modeled GMST and ΔGMST variations.The annual means for ENSO-years refer to the annual averages calculated from July to the following June. a Observed GMST anomalies (°C), relative to 1851–1900 climatology, during the period of 1881–2024. Gray shading marks the 95% confidence interval. b Observed and modeled ΔGMST variations from 1882 to 2024. The symbol Δ denotes the change in a variable, specifically referring to the interannual change between two consecutive ENSO years (i.e., \({\Delta {{{\rm{GMST}}}}}_{{{{\rm{ENSO}}}}-{{{\rm{year}}}}2024}={{{{\rm{GMST}}}}}_{{{{\rm{ENSO}}}}-{{{\rm{year}}}}2024}-{{{{\rm{GMST}}}}}_{{{{\rm{ENSO}}}}-{{{\rm{year}}}}2023}\)). Light blue shading in (b) represents the spread in the model’s ensemble results, while the dark blue line (dot) indicates the ensemble mean. In (a) and (b), red open circles indicate the El Niño years (1983, 1998, 2016, and 2024). The blue dots represent the modeled GMST and ΔGMST values for ENSO-year 2024. c The probability distributions of the bias of the model (see Methods) are derived from the difference between the model’s ensemble outputs and the observations presented in (b) during the period from ENSO-year 1881 to 2023 (gray shading) and ENSO-year 2024 (blue shading), respectively. The modeled values in (b,c) are obtained from the GMST forecast model.Full size imageThe 2023-24 El Niño, measured by tropical eastern Pacific SST, was less intense than historic extremes (1982–83, 1997–98, and 2015–16), yet the associated ΔGMST far exceeded that of past episodes. The mechanisms behind this striking discrepancy and the unprecedented ΔGMST are not completely understood, underscoring the need for further investigation.In this study, we identify the potential factors that contributed to the unprecedented ΔGMST during the 2023–24 El Niño event. The results reveal the decisive role of SST in elevating GMST and underscore the synergistic effects of the 2023–24 El Niño across the tropical oceans.ResultsObservations and model results of GMST in 2024Since the 1970s, GMST has exhibited a consistent warming trend (Fig. 1a), largely driven by anthropocentric forcing20,21. Nevertheless, the warming rates calculated over shorter intervals have shown considerable fluctuations, due to the intrinsic variability inherent in the climate system on annual to decadal timescales10,15,16,22,23,24. On inter-annual timescales, El Niño events in particular, especially extremes such as in 1982-83, 1997-98, and 2015-16, lead to notable spikes in GMST14 (red open circles in Fig. 1a, b).Considering various factors (Supplementary Fig. 2), we have implemented a simple yet effective physically-based forecast model for annual-mean GMST variations. The model, named GMST forecast model (Eq. (1–2)), can effectively describe ΔGMST during ENSO-years10. The predictors consist of greenhouse gas emissions, ENSO influences, stratospheric sulfate aerosols produced by volcanoes, and the damping rate of the climate system10,15. Among these predictors, the impact of ENSO is measured by the annual mean TNINO index, which is an average of SST anomalies in the region 160°E–90°W and 5°S–5°N (dashed black rectangle in Fig. 2a), calculated from July to June10,15. When the observed predictor values prior to 2024 are input into the model, the model can accurately hindcast ΔGMST (Fig. 1b) with a root-mean-square error (RMSE) of approximately 0.07 °C (Fig. 1c)10.Fig. 2: Observed and GSFM modeled global surface temperature variations for ENSO-year 2024.a Observed and c modeled anomalies of SST and LAT for ENSO-year 2024, relative to 1951–1980 climatology. White lines denote the 1.4 °C and 1.7 °C contours in the tropical Pacific, highlighting the spatial patterns. The regions with record-breaking heating are marked with blue dots. The same color scale is applied to both (a) and (c). b,d are the same as (a,c), but for ΔSST and ΔLAT, respectively. e The explained variances of observed ΔSST and ΔLAT by the GSFM (shading) and ENSO (doted for exceeding 20%). f The model bias for ENSO-year 2024 relative to the observations, along with its normalized value (contours for exceeding 1 standard deviation) derived from the period of 1882−2023 (see Method). All years are ENSO-years, defined by the July–June time frame. The white spots in (c–f) are due to data gaps in GISTEMP.Full size imageGiven the potential for extreme heat associated with the 2023–24 El Niño event, we published a forecast of GMST for ENSO-year 2024 using this model, which includes estimated values of the predictors10 (Supplementary Fig. 2). Under an El Niño scenario of moderate or stronger amplitude (Supplementary Fig. 3), characterized by a TNINO index greater than 0.6 °C, GMST was projected to be in the range of 1.30 to 1.47 °C above pre-industrial levels, with a 90% likelihood of surpassing historical records10. However, even the upper boundary of the prediction range was lower than the observed values.Compared to observations, the estimated values of all predictors—greenhouse gases, aerosols, and El Niño intensity—were within reasonable ranges (Supplementary Fig. 2). The spread in GMST predictions primarily arises from the uncertainties in estimating El Niño intensity (Supplementary Fig. 3)10. Notably, the observed TNINO index was far lower than the historical extreme values (Supplementary Fig. 2c). When incorporating the actual observed predictors in ENSO-year 2024 into the GMST forecast model, the estimated ΔGMST is only 0.16 °C. This stands in striking contrast to the observed ΔGMST of 0.36 °C, which substantially exceeded all previous records (Fig. 1b). This bias obviously deviated from the distribution of historical errors (Fig. 1c), suggesting that the GMST forecast model was inadequate for predicting the extreme ΔGMST in ENSO-year 2024. Given the model’s good historical performance, this notable underestimation of ΔGMST not only exposes the complexity of GMST changes but also suggests the distinctiveness of this specific ENSO-year.Observed and modeled spatial distribution of surface temperature in 2024 ENSO-yearTo predict the spatial distribution of surface temperature, including SST and land air temperature (LAT), we have extended the GMST forecast model to encompass each 2° × 2° grid point across the globe10.This model, named the Global surface temperature Spatial Forecast Model (GSFM) (Eq. (3)), operates as a patchwork, independently simulating inter-annual increments in surface temperature (ΔSST & ΔLAT) for each grid point and then amalgamating them to create a spatial distribution. The final predictions for the surface temperature distribution are derived by adding these increments to the current state10.Accordingly, we hindcast the spatial pattern of ΔSST & ΔLAT (Fig. 2d) in ENSO-year 2024, based on the observed values of the predictors. Subsequently, the prediction for the surface temperature anomalies in ENSO-year 2024 (Fig. 2c) is obtained by adding the increment (Fig. 2d) to the surface temperature anomalies in ENSO-year 2023. Model bias is defined as the difference between the GSFM prediction and observations (see Methods). Given that the modeled ΔGMST value of the GSFM is equal to that of the GMST forecast model, analyzing the spatial distribution of this bias (Fig. 2f) enables us to identify the potential causes of the GMST underestimation.During the 2023–24 El Niño, record-breaking temperatures were observed over extensive regions of the globe (Fig. 2a). In the tropical regions, these were mainly located in the Atlantic and the western Indian Ocean, as well as in the adjacent land areas. In extra-tropical regions, key areas of warming included the Eurasian continent, the northwest Pacific, and the northeastern part of North America.Statistically, based on the explained variance calculated for ENSO years from 1882 to 2023, the GSFM exhibits good predictive capabilities for tropical SSTs (Fig. 2e), largely due to ENSO teleconnections to these regions. In contrast, the GSFM has a relatively low explained variance in extratropical regions (Fig. 2e). Overall, the hindcast of surface temperature increment in the tropical oceans, Amazon and Alaska (Fig. 2d) were similar in pattern to the observations (Fig. 2b). The pattern correlation between the predicted SST & LAT with observed values is approximately 0.94, while the correlation for predicted and observed ΔSST & ΔLAT is 0.66. However, both the extent and intensity of the hindcast surface temperature anomalies are much weaker compared to the observations (Fig. 2b vs. 2d), aligning with the underestimation in GMST (Fig. 1a). This limitation is evident even in tropical oceans, including the western Indian Ocean and part of the tropical Atlantic, where observed SSTs were poorly captured despite the overall high explained variance by the model in these regions. In addition, over the tropical Atlantic, a large portion of the high SST area lies outside the region with high explained variance.One possible reason for this underestimation is that the GSFM demonstrates relatively low prediction proficiency in extratropical regions (Fig. 2e). For instance, the estimated SST anomalies over the subtropical North Pacific and North Atlantic are underestimated by the model (Fig. 2f). In these two regions, the GSFM simulated cooling (Fig. 2d) in contrast to the observed warming (Fig. 2b).Another possible explanation for this underestimation is that the TNINO index we use ref. 10 overlooks the diversity of ENSO and may therefore underestimate its global impact. Specifically, tropical Pacific SST anomalies during the 2023–24 El Niño exhibited a double-peak spatial structure over the central and eastern Pacific 2a). However, the TNINO index alone fails to capture this spatial structure, as shown by the comparison between Fig. 2a, c. This representation of tropical Pacific SSTs may lead to substantial underestimation of ENSO’s impacts, particularly in terms of its influence on SSTs across other tropical ocean basins25,26.Additionally, atmospheric internal variability is also a key factor contributing to the record-breaking GMST27,28. In particular, atmospheric internal variability in the extra-tropical Northern Hemisphere is recognized as the second largest source of GMST variability after ENSO29. However, for interannual predictions, atmospheric internal variability remains challenging to accurately capture, and so is the leading source of the disagreement between observations and predicted GMST. Therefore, here we primarily focus on tropical SSTs, as they are typically well-correlated with ENSO and exhibit higher predictability.Contributions of SST anomalies in various basins to GMSTGlobal surface temperature is closely tied to the state of SST2,30. The component of GMST variability originating from global or regional SST variability encompasses both the direct contribution from SST magnitude and the indirect contribution from SST-pattern effect30. As an integral component of GMST, a rise in SST (ΔSST) directly drives an increase in GMST (ΔGMST), reflecting the direct contribution from SST values. However, SST variations across different geographic regions influence LAT to varying degrees. In turn, the same magnitude of SST change in one region may have a different effect on GMST than in another region. This phenomenon is termed the SST-pattern effect30,31,32, which constitutes the indirect effect of SST on GMST.A Green’s Function (GF) approach enables us to quantify the component of interannual (or monthly) GMST variability originating from SST forcing at each grid point (Methods)23,30,33. The approach makes no assumptions about the causes of SST variability. For a given SST anomaly field, GF estimates its influence on GMST variability for the given month or year, regardless of whether that SST anomaly field is forced or natural. Following the definition from previous studies23,30,32, the GMST estimated from the SST field via the GF is designated as SST-correction.Following this definition, the SST-correction encapsulates both the direct contribution from the magnitude of SST anomalies and the indirect contribution from the SST-pattern effect. The former can be calculated through area weighting of SST. For example, weighted global or regional ΔSST is ΔSST adjusted by the percentage of global or regional ocean area relative to the global surface, ensuring proportional contributions. The residual, defined as the SST-pattern effect, is quantified by the difference between the SST-correction and weighted ΔSST, which captures the influence of ΔSST spatial configurations on LAT.Taking the observed ΔSST into the GF framework, the observed ΔGMST is well reconstructed by the global SST-correction (see Methods; Supplementary Fig. 7), with an RMSE of approximately 0.07 °C. This error amplitude is comparable to what is typically seen in the GMST forecast model (Fig. 1c). Unlike with the GMST forecast model (Eq. (1)), the record-breaking ΔGMST in ENSO-year 2024 can be calculated quite accurately (Fig. 3b & Supplementary Fig. 7). The SST-correction is 0.34 °C, with a bias of -0.02 °C, and the weighted global ΔSST is 0.18 °C. These values underscore the decisive role of SST.Fig. 3: Observed and GSFM modeled SST-correction.In (a), the observed ΔSST induced corrections to ΔGMST in ENSO-year 2024 are presented. In (b), SST-correction and weighted ΔSST of different oceans in ENSO-year 2024 from observations are displayed. The SST-pattern effect is quantified by the difference between the SST-correction (red bar) and weighted ΔSST (blue bar). c, d are similar to (a, b), but for the modeled ΔSST (shown in Fig. 2d). The black dots in (b) and (d) represent the observed ΔGMST. e, f illustrate the differences in SST-correction and weighted ΔSST between the observed and modeled ΔSST. The domains for the Indian Ocean (IO: 15°S–20°N, 40°E –120°E), the tropical Pacific (TP: 15°S–15°N, 150°E –90°W), and the tropical North Atlantic (TNA: 0°–30°N, 60°W –0°) are marked in (a). In the left column, the percentage accounted for in the observed ΔGMST is shown on the left-hand y-axis. SST-correction methods are detailed in Methods.Full size imageClearly, tropical SSTs contribute most to the ΔGMST (Fig. 3a). The sum of the SST-corrections across the tropical Pacific, Indian Ocean, and tropical North Atlantic regions reaches 0.29 °C, accounting for 80% of the observed ΔGMST (Fig. 3b).The ΔGMST value from the GSFM, which is equal to that of the GMST forecast model, can be partitioned into the ΔSST and ΔLAT components. The weighted global ΔSST from the GSFM is about 0.11 °C (Fig. 3d). Since the modeled ΔSST or ΔLAT for each grid point is simulated independently10, there is no specific manifestation for the SST-pattern effect from the modeled ΔSST pattern. Taking the modeled ΔSST (Fig. 2d) from the GSFM into the GF framework (Fig. 3c), the global SST-correction is 0.20 °C (Fig. 3d), which is 25% higher than our hindcast value of 0.16 °C but still below the observed 0.36 °Ç. This probably indicates that SST other than those closely related to ENSO (TNINO index) have an influence on LAT, and this influence is not strongly linked to TNINO index.The decisive role of SST in determining GMST suggests that accurate ΔSST from the GSFM output, combined with an SST correction from the GF framework, could potentially predict the record-breaking ΔGMST more accurately. Thus, the underestimated ΔSST is a key factor in the model’s underestimation of our previously published prediction of ΔGMST9. Next, we examine the discrepancies in SST-correction (Fig. 3e) derived from the modeled ΔSST (Fig. 2d) and the observed ΔSST (Fig. 2b) to determine which ocean basin’s ΔSST underestimation had the most notable impact.The most prominent negative difference is located in the tropical central Pacific (Fig. 3e), highlighting that the underestimation of ΔSST in this region has the most notable impact on ΔGMST. Per thermal wind theory, this extension is primarily driven by the meridional temperature gradient (Supplementary Fig. 11), which correlates with the preceding SST warming patterns (Fig. 5b).An Earth’s energy imbalance (EEI) perspectiveFor the entire climate system, all energy entering or exiting the system is transferred via radiation at the top-of-atmosphere (TOA). The TOA energy budget is determined by the amount of incoming net absorbed shortwave (solar) radiation (ASR) and the outgoing longwave (thermal) radiation (OLR). The Earth’s Energy Imbalance (EEI) can be measured by net TOA radiation downward \({{{{\rm{R}}}}}_{{{{\rm{T}}}}}={{{\rm{ASR}}}}-{{{\rm{OLR}}}}\), which arises from multiple factors: forcing, feedback, and internal variability57.EEI causes heating of the planet, which is manifested in multiple ways, including ice melt, land warming, and a rise in ocean heat content (OHC). Changes in GMST on the other hand are related to surface temperatures (LAT and SST). Therefore, both GMST and EEI are influenced by the same factors in Eq. (1). It has been well understood that the accumulation of carbon dioxide reduces the amount of infrared radiation emitted to space, leading to planetary-scale energy accumulation58,59, while the anthropogenic and volcanic aerosols can cool the climate system by reflecting sunlight back to space. In addition, ENSO can cause year-to-year fluctuations in EEI49,60. Generally, during La Niña phases, the EEI increases, representing a net energy gain for the Earth system. By contrast, during El Niño phases, the EEI decreases, indicating a net energy loss from the system57,60,61. The cold and warm ENSO phases also correspond to the recharge and discharge of OHC, which in turn influences the variations in GMST60,61. The 2023–24 El Niño with dual warming centers in the central and eastern tropical Pacific amplified GMST to a greater extent than typical El Niño events captured in our hindcast results. The spatiotemporal evolution characteristics of this El Niño event, combined with the eastward North Atlantic jet stream extension, contributed to greater SST increases in the tropical Indian Ocean and North Atlantic. First, while our analysis demonstrates that the SST-correction in the tropical Atlantic and Indian Oceans is related to ENSO, the GF methodology—based on temporally coincident variations—does not quantify the Pacific El Niño’s lagged impacts (e.g., seasonally delayed TNA warming and Indian Ocean basin mode development). Internal variability and anthropogenic forcing likely played a role in shaping this El Niño event’s atypical teleconnection patterns by preconditioning an eastward shift of the Atlantic jet stream, which subsequently amplified regional SST responses. This raises important questions about whether these exceptional teleconnections resulted purely from stochastic variability or reflected preconditioning by decadal variations in background states. Furthermore, the limited predictability of extratropical regions is closely tied to atmospheric internal variability28,66.                 where \({T}_{S}\) is SST, \({Q}_{\downarrow }\) represents the net surface heat flux (positive downwards), \({Q}_{h}\) is the penetrative shortwave radiation, \({\rho }_{o}\) is the density of seawater, \({c}_{p}\) is the specific heat capacity of seawater, \(h\) signifies the mixed layer depth. The residual, \({Res}\), represents the combined effect of all oceanic dynamic processes on SST, including incuding horizontal advection and eddy transport, and vertical advection and mixing, on SST. The net surface heat flux (\({Q}_{\downarrow }\)) is comprised of net downward shortwave radiation (\({Q}_{{SW}}\)), net longwave radiation (\({Q}_{{LW}}\)), latent heat flux (\({Q}_{L}\)), and sensible heat flux (\({Q}_{S}\)).$${Q}_{\downarrow }={Q}_{{SW}}+{Q}_{{LW}}+{Q}_{L}+{Q}_{S}$$
                    (5)
                Penetrative radiation, \({Q}_{h}\), is computed as ref. 83 \({Q}_{h}={Q}_{{SW}}({0.58e}^{-\frac{h}{0.35}}+{0.42e}^{-\frac{h}{23}})\). Note that all heat flux terms here are defined as positive when directed from the atmosphere to the ocean.According to Eq. (4), net surface heat flux anomalies (\({Q}_{\downarrow }\)) are directly related to the tendency changes in SST (\(\frac{\partial {T}_{s}}{\partial t}\)). The daily variables from ERA5 are used for analysis in Fig. 5a. We mainly focused on the correlation between the changes in \({Q}_{\downarrow }\) and \(\frac{\partial {{T}}_{{{s}}}}{\partial {t}}\), since \({Q}_{h}\) values are generally small.RWS and WAFThe 200 hPa RWS is calculated as56:$${RWS}=-{\zeta }_{a}D-\bar{{v}_{\chi }}.\nabla {\zeta }_{a}$$
                    (6)
                RWS is computed using the magnitudes of the divergence \({{D}}\), the absolute vorticity \({{{\zeta }}}_{{{a}}}\), and the irrotational component of the wind \(\bar{{v}}_{{{\chi }}}\). The 200 hPa RWS is calculated by the NCEP/NCAR reanalysis monthly products at a 2.5°× 2.5° resolution.The horizontal 200 hPa WAF is also used to explore the stationary RWS and wave propagation, which is calculated as53:$$W= \frac{1}{2|{\bar{{{\boldsymbol{U}}}}}|}\left(\begin{array}{c}{\bar{u}}\left({\psi {{\hbox{'}}}_{x}}^{2}-\psi {\hbox{'}}{\psi {\hbox{'}}}_{xx}\right)+{\bar{v}}\left({\psi {\hbox{'}}}_{x}{\psi {\hbox{'}}}_{y}-\psi {\hbox{'}}{\psi {\hbox{'}}}_{xy}\right)\\ {\bar{u}}\left({\psi {\hbox{'}}}_{x}{\psi {\hbox{'}}}_{y}-\psi {\hbox{'}}{\psi {\hbox{'}}}_{xy}\right)+{\bar{v}}\left({{\psi {\hbox{'}}}_{y}}^{2}-\psi {\hbox{'}}{\psi {\hbox{'}}}_{yy}\right)\end{array}\right)$$
                    (7)
                Where the overbars and primes denote the climatology and its deviation, the subscripts x and y represent the zonal and meridional gradients, respectively, \(\psi\) is the stream function, and \(|\bar{{{{\boldsymbol{U}}}}}|\) is the magnitude of the climatological wind. The climatological seasonal cycle from 1991 to 2020 is removed to derive the anomaly of each variable (Supplementary Fig. 9).

items.title: I ghiacciai affronteranno un “picco di estinzione” alla metà del secolo
items.description: Uno studio spiega che, nella fase di “picco”, perderemo tra 2 e 4mila ghiacciai all’anno. Quelli delle Alpi tra i primi a scomparire.
items.body:
Cosa dice l’ultimo rapporto sullo stato del clima in Europa? Che la crisi climatica è già qui
		
		
			Il nuovo rapporto Copernicus-Omm illustra lo stato del clima in Europa. I dati relativi al 2023 sono inquietanti, ma crescono le rinnovabili.
		
		
			 Cambiamenti climatici
			22 aprile 2024
			
				di Andrea Barolini

Ripartiamo dalla montagna
		
		
			Con il Club alpino italiano (Cai) raccontiamo le sfide e opportunità delle terre alte, da un approccio più consapevole alla loro tutela e valorizzazione.
		
		
			 Ambiente
			23 marzo 2024
			
				di Camilla Soldati

Crollo della Marmolada, uno studio conferma che è colpa della crisi climatica
		
		
			Secondo il primo studio a indagare le cause del crollo della Marmolada, costato la vita 11 persone, l’evento è  dovuto in gran parte alle alte temperature.
		
		
			 Ambiente
			18 aprile 2023
			
				di Redazione

Le inondazioni da collasso di laghi glaciali mettono a rischio circa 15 milioni di persone
			
			
				Man mano che aumentano le temperature e i ghiacciai fondono, le inondazioni da collasso di laghi glaciali diventano più frequenti. E pericolose.

Cambiamenti climatici

9 febbraio 2023

Per metà dei ghiacciai della Terra non c’è più speranza
			
			
				Uno studio pubblicato da Science spiega che anche centrando gli obiettivi climatici più ambiziosi, la metà dei ghiacciai terrestri non sopravvivrà.

Cambiamenti climatici

9 gennaio 2023

Gran Paradiso, cosa insegnano 100 anni di storia sul futuro della conservazione
			
			
				Un racconto dal Parco nazionale del Gran Paradiso per dar voce a chi da anni vive e studia questo territorio per proteggerlo dalla crisi climatica.

items.title: EBA Statistical Report 2025: continua la crescita del biogas in Europa
items.description: EBA, l’Associazione europea del biogas, di cui il CIB è parte, ha pubblicato in questi giorni la nuova edizione dello Statistical Report, il documento
items.body:
EBA Statistical Report 2025: continua la crescita del biogas in Europa

11 Dicembre 2025

EBA, l’Associazione europea del biogas, di cui il CIB è parte, ha pubblicato in questi giorni la nuova edizione dello Statistical Report, il documento che fotografa ogni anno la situazione del settore del biogas e del biometano in Europa. Il rapporto sottolinea l’urgente necessità di potenziare le soluzioni nazionali basate sul gas rinnovabile. Il biogas offre una via diretta per ridurre la dipendenza energetica strategica, aumentando al contempo la competitività dell’Europa nella sua ambizione di eliminare gradualmente i combustibili fossili.  l’EBA Statistical Report 2025, rivela ancora una volta una crescita della produzione di biogas e biometano (22 miliardi di metri cubi nel 2024, rispetto ai 21,7 miliardi di metri cubi del 2023), concentrata principalmente nei paesi dell’UE-27 (19 miliardi di metri cubi). Il biometano continua a essere il segmento in più rapida crescita (5,2 miliardi di metri cubi, di cui 4,3 prodotti nell’UE-27), sostenuto da una capacità installata di 7 miliardi di metri cubi all’anno in Europa entro l’inizio del 2025.Inoltre, nel 2024 l’Europa ha prodotto 25 Mt (DM) di digestato. Il suo ruolo consolidato come ammendante e fertilizzante organico si sta espandendo, con nuovi percorsi di valorizzazione che stanno guadagnando slancio.Il rapporto completo è acquistabile sul sito di EBA ed è possibile rivedere il webinar di presentazione ai seguenti link.Consulta il comunicato stampaGuarda la registrazione del webinarGuarda le slide del webinarAcquista il rapporto completo (non soci)

items.title: Una sfida difficile ma non rinviabile
items.description: Pochi mesi fa, nella primavera 2025, il fisico Antonello Pasini, ricercatore Cnr e noto divulgatore, oltre che animatore del comitato La Scienza al Vo
items.body:
Una sfida difficile ma non rinviabile                
												
																																	                
					Dic 5, 2025Dic 5, 2025

Pochi mesi fa, nella primavera 2025, il fisico Antonello Pasini, ricercatore Cnr e noto divulgatore, oltre che animatore del comitato La Scienza al Voto, ha dato alle stampe un agile volumetto di 163 pagine intitolato “La sfida climatica. Dalla scienza alla politica: ragioni per il cambiamento” (Codice Edizioni, 2025, 18€).

Nel libro l’autore affronta, in ogni capitolo e in rapida sequenza, le diverse sfaccettature della sfida complessa che ci troviamo a fronteggiare: nel primo capitolo si discute della sfida scientifica e conoscitiva, nel secondo di quella filosofica e della visione del mondo, nel terzo di quella comunicativa, con alcune proposte e soluzioni, e nel quarto di quella politica. Un quinto capitolo, infine, è dedicato alla sfida forse più difficile, quella delle azioni da intraprendere per fronteggiare la crisi climatica.

Il tema scientifico occupa buona parte del libro, 64 pagine in cui Pasini affronta il difficile compito di riassumere la questione climatica odierna in termini comprensibili a chiunque, presentando una panoramica rigorosa e accessibile del fenomeno del cambiamento climatico, smontando luoghi comuni (“Il clima è sempre cambiato”, “Siamo troppo piccoli per influenzare il clima”) e sottolineando l’importanza di una solida conoscenza scientifica come base per le azioni. Non si tratta però di un’esposizione di tipo didattico, quanto piuttosto di una discussione di alcuni aspetti controversi, come per esempio il tema dell’attribuzione degli eventi estremi cui assistiamo con sempre maggior frequenza (ultima in Italia l’alluvione e la frana in Friuli del 17 novembre 2025); eventi attribuiti sempre più spesso non al caso, ma alle responsabilità di “Homo fossilis”, emettitore di enormi quantità di carbonio estratto dal sottosuolo e incessantemente bruciato in motori, caldaie e forni.

Nel capitolo “filosofico” (virgolette dell’autore) si affronta molto brevemente un tema in effetti enorme, quello del rapporto tra umanità e natura; o, meglio, della visione che l’uomo ha di se stesso come “dominatore del creato”, da sostituire con un approccio antitetico, dato che, come scrive Pasini, “i cambiamenti climatici ci mostrano un mondo diverso da quello che per lungo tempo abbiamo immaginato. Per adattarci a questo nuovo mondo, avremo bisogno di rivedere il nostro rapporto con gli ecosistemi, con gli esseri che li abitano e con i fenomeni inanimati che li pervadono. Avremo bisogno di un cambiamento filosofico, che parte e si intreccia con la conoscenza scientifica”. Si tratta di un programma davvero vasto che non sembra facile da perseguire, visto che in quasi ogni angolo del mondo già ai bambini si inculca il concetto che profitto e soldi sono le cose che più contano nella vita. In ogni caso, la tematica del cambio di paradigma filosofico si intreccia con quella  della comunicazione, anch’essa vastissima, che viene affrontata nel terzo capitolo.

Qui Pasini tocca diverse corde care ai frequentatori di Climalteranti, per esempio la diffusione sempre più pervasiva di disinformazione scientifica sul clima, in particolare sul web e sui social media, lo spazio sempre molto limitato e frammentario che i media più tradizionali dedicano alla questione climatica, la polarizzazione delle opinioni, che tende a prevalere persino sula formazione scientifica dei cittadini e che impedisce di rendersi conto della fondatezza fattuale delle opinioni altrui. Su questa tematica cruciale Pasini produce tre proposte di azione, la prima consiste nel “far parlare i due emisferi cerebrali” ovvero comunicare sia alla sfera razionale che a quella emotiva delle persone, contaminando la comunicazione scientifica con altri linguaggi, per esempio arte musica o teatro, insistere con i media perché si eviti il termine “maltempo” quando si descrivono eventi estremi causati dal nuovo clima, e anzi si faccia sempre menzione della causa primaria di ciò che sta accadendo, ovvero l’emissione continua di enormi quantità di carbonio fossile in atmosfera, infine comunicare la scienza del clima, insieme ai suoi metodi, senza tensioni muscolari ma “rispettando i valori di tutti” e condividendo le angosce e preoccupazioni che ognuno di noi prova quando si confronta col presente e col futuro.

Più in generale il libro si mostra anche come una sorta di sintetica spiegazione di quanto Pasini stesso stia cercando di fare, al di là delle sue importanti ricerche, per arrivare a istituzionalizzare in Italia il rapporto tra politica e scienza del clima. Come si diceva all’inizio, infatti, da ormai sette anni l’autore anima un gruppo piuttosto folto di studiosi denominato collettivamente comitato La scienza al voto, che ha prodotto, in particolare prima delle più importanti tornate elettorali, diversi “manifesti” e petizioni alla politica perché prenda sul serio, e in modo trasversale, la questione climatica, basandosi sulle risultanze scientifiche; e non affidandosi a primo che capita, purché dica quel che il politico di turno desidera sentirsi dire.

Più di recente Pasini ha promosso la creazione anche in Italia di un comitato consultivo permanente e ufficiale, denominato CSCA (Consiglio scientifico clima e ambiente), composto da studiosi selezionati non dalla politica ma dal mondo scientifico stesso, in ottemperanza alla recente Legge europea sul clima, che propugna l’istituzione di queste strutture sia a scala europea che nazionale.

Tornando al libro, va detto che, nonostante la sua brevità, risulta impegnativo per il lettore, dato che affronta diverse questioni complesse: dalla scienza alla comunicazione, alla politica, fino all’azione pratica. Il suo punto di forza è la capacità di Pasini di unire il rigore scientifico alla chiarezza divulgativa, offrendo un percorso che va dall’analisi dei processi in atto allo sviluppo di possibili soluzioni. Non si limita a gridare all’allarme, ma costruisce un ragionamento robusto che chiama in causa scienziati, cittadini e politici, evidenziando che l’unica incertezza non è più la crisi in sé, ma la nostra risposta. È una lettura essenziale per acquisire una maggiore consapevolezza della portata trasversale della crisi climatica e delle azioni urgenti che tutti siamo chiamati a compiere, individualmente e collettivamente. Potrà quindi essere apprezzato anche dagli “esperti” dei diversi rami perché possano ragionare “out of the box” e cogliere questioni di cui di solito non si occupano. Sicuramente una sfida anche questa, per riprendere il titolo.

Testo di Vittorio Marletto e Claudio Cassardo

items.title: Report BIP: digestato e biogas agricolo leve strategiche della bioeconomia circolare
items.description: Lo scorso 2 dicembre, nel corso di un recente evento tenutosi a Bruxelles, sono stati presentati i nuovi dati relativi alla produzione europea di biog
items.body:
Report BIP: digestato e biogas agricolo leve strategiche della bioeconomia circolare

5 Dicembre 2025

Lo scorso 2 dicembre, nel corso di un recente evento tenutosi a Bruxelles, sono stati presentati i nuovi dati relativi alla produzione europea di biogas e alla valorizzazione del digestato. L’analisi, illustrata da Piero Gattoni, Presidente dell’European Biogas Association (EBA) e del CIB – Consorzio Italiano Biogas, ha evidenziato un cambiamento strutturale nel settore: negli ultimi dodici anni la produzione di biogas è triplicata, confermando il ruolo strategico dell’agricoltura nella transizione energetica dell’Unione Europea.Al centro del dibattito non vi è solo la produzione energetica, ma l’affermazione di un modello di economia circolare ormai sistemico. Come emerge anche dal report “Use and Valorisation of Digestates: A Practical Review“ pubblicato dalla Biomethane Industrial Partnership (BIP), il digestato rappresenta una risorsa chiave in questo processo. Residuo del processo di digestione anaerobica, il digestato è un materiale organico arricchito di nutrienti che, restituito ai suoli, permette di chiudere il ciclo biologico delle aziende agricole.L’utilizzo agronomico del digestato offre una valida alternativa ai fertilizzanti di origine fossile, riducendo la dipendenza da processi produttivi energivori e contribuendo alla sicurezza degli approvvigionamenti. Inoltre, l’applicazione al suolo di questa materia organica stabilizzata favorisce lo stoccaggio di carbonio organico, mitigando le emissioni e migliorando la fertilità dei terreni.L’integrazione delle filiere, l’uso di tecnologie di precisione e il riutilizzo della CO₂ biogenica dimostrano come il biogas sia una leva concreta della bioeconomia. Il quadro che emerge è quello di un’agricoltura europea capace di generare energia rinnovabile, rigenerare i suoli e contribuire attivamente alla decarbonizzazione. Affinché questa trasformazione possa accelerare e consolidarsi, il settore richiede ora una visione politica stabile e un quadro normativo chiaro per il futuro.I contenuti del reportCapitolo 1Produzione europea di digestato: di cosa stiamo parlando?Come la digestione anaerobica influisce sulle proprietà del digestato?Caratteristiche del digestato intero (tal quale)Uso attuale dei digestati non trattatiCapitolo 2 Buone pratiche e principi europei per un uso diretto sicuro ed efficace dei digestati in agricolturaRidurre le emissioni di ammoniaca e metano e la lisciviazione dei nitratiSeparazione delle frazioni liquida e solida del digestatoApplicazione e stoccaggio della frazione liquida del digestatoApplicazione e stoccaggio della frazione solida del digestatoCapitolo 3Dal digestato ai fertilizzanti avanzati a base di digestatoBuone pratiche per prodotti fertilizzanti a base di digestato più avanzati/trattatiBarriere tecniche allo sviluppo di prodotti fertilizzanti a base di digestatoCapitolo 4 Portare sul mercato europeo fertilizzanti a base di digestato più avanzati/trattatiModelli di business per impianti di biogas con digestatiIl ruolo della regolamentazione e del sostegno politico per l’emergere della fertilizzazione organica in Europa
